titleStmt.title: Minutes of the TEI Technical Council
titleStmt.meeting: TEI Technical Council online meeting : 28 July 2015

sourceDesc.p: Retagged from a WordPress HTML file

revisionDesc.change: Extracted from Word Press article with id post-21927

list.item: Syd Bauman (SB)
Fabio Ciotti (FC)
Hugh Cayless (HC)
Martin Holmes (MH)
Peter Stadler (PWS)
Raff Viglianti (RV)
James Cummings @ 14:23 (JC)
Paul Schaffner @ 14:07 (PS)
Stefanie Gehrke (SG)
Lou Burnard (LB)
Reasons for leaving: wobbly infrastructure, shady practices, technology unlikely to improve. Are there good reasons to stay?
should we move to Git / GitHub? Are there alternatives we want to explore?

row.cell: Stylesheets and Simple are already there.
Slightly better integration of ticketing and commits.
Slightly higher learning curve for new users.
Pull requests / opportunity for better community engagement
Need to rewrite/update a ton of documentation and links.

list.item:
what needs to be replicated:
Keep presence on SF to avoid malware take-over. Possibly keep automatic mirror from GitHub
repository / software
issue tracking
file downloads (move to tei-c?)
Files can be attached to GitHub releases (tags)
migration of issues: could be a tool: https://github.com/cmungall/gosf2github appears to be feasible for the migration of issues
The difficult thing is that the creator might get lost and the user using the API will be the new ‚Äúcreator‚Äù.
TravisCI in addition to / instead of Jenkins?
Timeline if we do move
Action on SM to produce a spreadsheet with info from tc documents that will need to be updated if we move to GH.
Action on MH to do an inventory of the SF site and produce a report on what‚Äôs there.
Action on HC to put a self-updating copy of the SF repo in github‚Äôs TEI-C account for safety‚Äôs sake and for testing.
Action on RV to look into the process of migrating issues from SF to GH.
Action on JC to investigate users on SF account and find out if they have GH accounts.
Sun 10-25 / Tue 10-27 in Lyon
will be getting meeting room from U on Mon 26 and Tue 27
need to find meeting room for Sun 25 ‚Äî one not available, the other ‚Ç¨900
WiFi is a requirement, projection is a desirable
Action on HC to look for ‚Äúwork space‚Äù or ‚Äúshare space‚Äù in addition to hotel meeting rooms
MH proposes returning to the old content model and implementing the restriction in Schematron.
Council agrees: YES!
Action on MH to raise a separate ‚Äús as child of s?‚Äù ticket
how do we allow encoder to say ‚Äúabout the source‚Äù vs ‚Äúabout this TEI file‚Äù

should content be
well-formed XML-only, or
any well-balanced XML, or
any (well-balanced) XML or text() ? (The latter to allow ‚Äúbinary‚Äù formats like JSON)
JC: I think we should make no rules about this other than that the document needs to be well-formed. (e.g. it can have text, CDATA sections, xml etc.)
The consensus is that anything (XML or text) should be allowed (of course it will need to be correctly escaped or encoded.) Stating the obvious: the result must be a well formed XML document.
HC: The issue of whether there should be a way to characterize what is in xenoData should be a separate ticket (@mimetype?).
FC: in Council Mail List I suggested to adopt something like @MDTYPE in METS

SB, MH, JC, FC remained on the call and discussed the nature of @rend‚Ä¶ because they are gluttons for punishment. MH and JC agree that order isn‚Äôt significant (by default at least), and SB thinks it should be, but is wrong. üòâ To clarify that a little ‚Äî MH and JC agree that the TEI should require that order not be significant, SB thinks that whether order is significant or not is up to the encoder / project / ODD-writer.

default values (SB)
SB, LB, SR suggestion ‚Äî make semantic suggestion rather than syntactic requirement
MH suggestion ‚Äî make part of att.deprecated and actually remove
